title: Deported for STALKING obsessed ex who hung a sign on a motorway bridge
text:
A 38-year-old man could be deported for stalking his ex for more than three months - bombarding her with calls and even hanging a sign for her on a motorway bridge.

The man, from the Gold Coast, has lived in Australia since he was seven-years-old after moving from New Zealand but never obtained citizenship, the Southport District Court heard on Thursday.

He is now at the mercy of the Home Affairs Minister as to whether he will be allowed to remain in the country, the Gold Coast Bulletin reported.

The court heard the man's conduct left his ex 'scared and anxious' and 'like a prisoner in her own home'.

The man, who cannot legally be named, has a criminal history of violence, including grabbing another woman 'by the mouth and pulling her hair'.

He pleaded guilty to unlawful stalking at Merrimac between October 21, 2018 and January 21, while on parole.

He also pleaded guilty to willful damage, five counts of contravening a domestic violence order and two counts of driving while his licence was disqualified by court order.

His defence argued for a sentence that would let him remain in the country with his children and other family.

Judge Suzanne Sheridan adjourned to consider her decision, returning to the matter Friday by handing down an 18 month sentence.

She said the sentence of more than 12 months made the defendant's 'position very precarious' and there was a 'real possibility' he 'could be deported'.

Considering the man has already served 257 days he is eligible for immediate parole release.

While the offences do not amount to an automatic deportation, Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton now has the discretion to deport the man.
